items.text: In general, people read left to right, top to bottom( unless any specific requirement e.g. Arabic content). Discuss and finalize the canvas size of the report page (as per the requirement & choice of visualizations, alignment etc.) and use the same across solution for consistency.
White or light backgrounds are printer friendly, ensuring our reports can be easily shared online and offline.

At most, show up to four numerals when displaying numbers. Be consistent across decimal points, limiting measures to two numerals to the right of the decimal point. When necessary, scale for thousands or millions.
Report tooltips are a great way of sharing additional information in a limited report space. Limit which visuals we use in report tooltips to ensure information isn’t overwhelming.

Power BI allows us to give aliases to report objects. Avoid ambiguity for end users when naming columns and measures by using business-friendly names. To avoid confusing users, consider hiding unused columns.

Enable “Personalize visuals” in report settings when sharing reports with users. This enables users to gain further insights through ad-hoc exploration. Combine this feature with personal bookmarks to enable self-service BI.

Multiple scrolls on a single page lead to a negative user experience. Limit our page size to the standard report sizes when possible. Use the Bookmark and Selection pane to toggle the visibility of visuals if needed.

Drillthrough buttons are more intuitive than right-click because they clearly signal actions and results to users. Use conditional formatting to ensure button text is context-driven, further enhancing the user experience.

Templates enable us to develop branded reports faster. With templates, we can save custom color palettes and themes, ensuring corporate branding is pre-applied to all pages. Templates also automatically connect to commonly used data sources and offer commonly used DAX measures.

3-D charts look good but they are harder to read than flat visuals.Be consistent with our designs — chart scales, dimensions, time frames, measurement scale, and even colors.Use only 3-4 numeric values when showing numbers — 1.34 million is better than 1,340,000.Use only data labels when necessary.
Remove unnecessary columnsRemove unnecessary rowsGroup by and summarizeOptimize column data typesDisable Power Query query loadDisable auto date/timeSwitch to Mixed mode
items.link: Data reduction techniques for Import modeling

items.text: Describes star schema design and its relevance to developing Power BI data models optimized for performance and usability.
items.link: Understand star schema and the importance for Power BI

items.text: Disable Power Query background refresh

Check if, Disable Auto date time intelligence for new files.You can use a single date table to reduce model size, placing any required relationships in fact tables. When building your date table, split the date and time to improve data compression

items.subcategory: Query Folding and Refer Native Query
items.text: Query folding guidance in Power BI Desktop

items.subcategory: Filter First, Calculations Later in Power BI
items.text: If for some reason the query cannot fold, such as when we are reading data from a non-relation source like a text file or Excel worksheet, it's important to reduce the size of the data set if possible. For example, if we need to filter on a column, we should better do it as one of the very first steps in the query. The same goes for removing columns. In short: filter first, calculations later.

items.subcategory: Use Power BI Functions for Reuse
items.text: If we have many queries with a common complex calculation: we should try to make a function out of it.

items.subcategory: Limit complex measures and aggregations in data models
items.text: Create calculated measures instead of calculated columns. Where possible, push calculated columns and measures to the source. The closer they are to the source, the faster they are likely to perform.

Slicers are a great way of allowing users to navigate data, but they come at a performance cost. Each slicer generates two queries: one fetches the data, the other fetches selection details. Adding too many slicers drastically slows performance. To remove unnecessary slicers, use the Filter pane to evaluate which slicers are used the least.

Reduce the number of queries sent by Power BI using the Query reduction settings. For slicers, select the “Add an Apply button to each slicer to apply changes when you’re ready” option. For filters, select “Add a single Apply button to the filter pane to apply changes at once (preview).”

Many-to-many and bi-directional relationships navigate more pathways and check more data points. As a result, bi-directional relationships against high-cardinality columns negatively impact report performance.

items.subcategory: Avoid using floating point data types
items.text: Floating point data types can result in unpredictable round-off errors and can decrease the performance of reports. Use Decimal or Fixed Decimal Data Type.

items.subcategory: Replace the auto-generated date table with a custom date table in your model
items.text: Using a date table enables you to leverage the time-series function in Power BI. However, the auto-generated date table creates a date table for each date column, drastically increasing the model size.

items.subcategory: Reduce the amount of data loaded on page load
items.text: Use drill-through pages, and tooltips to reduce the amount of data loaded on page load. This improves page load time for landing pages.
Three dataset modes :- Import, DirectQuery, Composite. Should consider the rationale for each mode, and possible impacts on Power BI capacity resources

items.subcategory: Ensure the cache update frequency aligns with the data source refresh frequency(DirectQuery and live connection datasets)
items.text: By default, the Power BI cache update frequency is set to one hour. Cache update frequency should be set at similar intervals to data source refresh frequency. If, for example, our data set refreshes only once per day, we should update the cache frequency accordingly. This improves report performance and accuracy for end users.

items.subcategory: Import only necessary fields and tables instead of entire data sets
items.text: Ensure the model is as narrow and lean as possible. Power BI works on columnar indexes, meaning longer and leaner tables perform better. If we need to import a large table, partition it and process multiple partitions in parallel.

items.subcategory: Data Warehouse or No Data Warehouse
items.text: For small ad-hoc analysis projects, such as analyzing the data from one text file, we  don't need a data warehouse. But if we see a particular data set being used all over the organization, or if multiple people make reports over the same data, it might be time for a centralized effort to create a data warehouse.
Apply the most restrictive filters i.e. use the 'Top N' filter to reduce the max number of items that the table displays.

Custom visuals can perform poorly when handling large datasets or complex aggregations. Uncertified custom visuals are generally not tested by the Power BI team. If a custom visual performs poorly, consider replacing it with a different visual.

items.subcategory: Limit the number of visuals in dashboards and reports
items.text: Using too many visuals on a single report slows report performance.

By default, all visuals on a report page can interact with one another. By disabling unnecessary interactions, you reduce the number of queries fired at the back end, which improves report performance.Please note , After enabling the setting (Disabling cross highlighting and filtering by default) in Query Reduction tab, newly added visuals will be automatically disabled for cross highlighting and filtering, but this will not take effect on the visuals created prior this setting.We need to make the interactions turned off for each pre-existing visual on the page.
It is very crucial to select the type of visualization to show the intended information to users

items.subcategory: Use report backgrounds for static images
items.text: For static images, use report backgrounds rather than multiple visuals. This conveys the same information to the end user at a fraction of the performance cost.
&nbsp

items.subcategory: Avoid using FILTER as a filter argument
items.text: &nbsp
&nbsp
&nbsp
&nbsp

items.subcategory: Use variables to improve your DAX formulas
items.text: &nbsp
&nbsp

items.subcategory: DAX Measures and Columns Naming Convention
items.text: When referencing columns in a measure, the naming conventions it to use TableName[ColumnName], while for measures we should use only the measure name. This convention makes it easy to distinguish between columns and measures in a DAX formula and avoids any confusion.
Using variables in DAX leads to better readable and understandable code. Sometimes it can also lead to a performance improvement because some parts of the formula need to be calculated only once.

items.subcategory: Try to Avoid DAX Iterator Functions
items.text: Refer an example in Link

In PBI Desktop, any column with numerical values can be used as a measure in a visualization, or it can be referenced in a measure. When we use such a column, it's an implicit measure. When we write a DAX formula to create a measure, it's an explicit measure. The best practice is to use explicit measures everywhere, even for simple measures like sum, min, max and average. The reason behind this is that if we use implicit measures in the formula of other measures and at some point the business logic changes – meaning we need to write a formula for this basic measure – we will need to update every single measure where this base measure was used. Explicit measures promote reusability and make it easier to refactor your code.

Row-Level Security restricts user access to certain rows in a database depending on the characteristics (role) of the user executing a query. With RLS, Power BI only imports data the user is authorized to view.

Object-level security (OLS) enables model authors to secure specific tables or columns from report viewers. From a viewer standpoint, the table or column simply does not exist. Currently OLS definitions are not created natively in Power BI Desktop, but external tools such as Tabular Editor can set OLS rules on Power BI Desktop datasets.

Power BI certified visuals are custom visuals on AppSource that have passed rigorous quality testing. Microsoft verifies that certified custom visuals have robust, high-performance code. Certified custom visuals are the only custom visuals that can be viewed in Export to PowerPoint mode and email subscriptions.

items.subcategory: Categorize report data by business impact
items.text: Use Power BI sensitivity labels to classify data as high, medium, or low business impact. High Business Impact (HBI) data requires users to request a policy exception to share the data externally. Low Business Impact (LBI) and Medium Business Impact (MBI) data do not require exceptions. By using Power BI data sensitivity labels, you raise user awareness about security and how reports should be shared inside and outside the organization.
One of the built-in tools is the performance analyzer, which gives  an overview of all the time spent on the various queries executed by your reports. Refer screenshot.
Open source community tool
Open source community tool
Keyboard navigationScreen-reader compatibilityHigh contrast colors viewFocus modeShow data table
Alt textTab orderTitles & labelsMarkersReport themes
To help users get the same information from a report as those who don’t use assistive technology.

items.subcategory: Ensure reports and data sources are in the same region
items.text: With the tenant and data source in the same region, we can limit the effects of network latency. Sharing a region ensures faster data transfer and faster query execution.

Best practicesUsing workspaces instead of personal workspaces.Separating business critical and Self-Service BI (SSBI) into different capacities.If sharing content only with Power BI Pro users, there may be no need to store the content in a reserved capacity.Use reserved capacities when looking to achieve a specific refresh time, or when specific features are required. For example, with large datasets or paginated reporting.Monitoring using Power BI Premium Capacity Metrics app
Use on-premises data gateway instead of Personal Gateway

items.subcategory: Large datasets in Power BI Premium
items.text: With Premium capacities, large datasets beyond the default limit can be enabled with the Large dataset storage format setting.

items.subcategory: Hasslefree deployment across different envrionments, workspaces
items.text: Deployment pipelines is designed as a pipeline with three stages:DevelopmentThis stage is used to design, build, and upload new content with fellow creators. This is the first stage in deployment pipelines.TestYou're ready to enter the test stage after you've made all the needed changes to your content. You upload the modified content so it can be moved to this test stage. Here are three examples of what can be done in the test environment:Share content with testers and reviewersLoad and run tests with larger volumes of dataTest your app to see how it will look for your end usersProductionAfter testing the content, use the production stage to share the final version of your content with business users across the organization.

You'll be able to access the deployment pipelines feature, if the following conditions are met:You have one of the following Premium licenses:You're a Power BI Pro user, and you belong to an organization that has Premium capacity.Premium Per User (PPU).You're an admin of a workspace.

Deployment pipelines offer three options when it comes to deploying your Power BI content:Deploying all content - Deploy all your Power BI content to the target stage.Selective deployment - Select which Power BI content to deploy to the target stage.Backwards deployment - Deploy your content to a previous stage in the pipeline.

items.subcategory: Automate your deployment pipeline using APIs and Azure DevOps
items.text: To achieve continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) of content, many organizations use various automation tools, including Azure DevOps. Organizations that use Azure DevOps, can use the Power BI automation tool extension, which supports many of the deployment pipelines API operations.
